title: CNN Fires Chris Cuomo Amid Inquiry Into His Efforts to Aid His Brother
content: The network said it had “terminated him, effective immediately,” a move that came days after a lawyer for a former colleague accused the host of sexual misconduct.

more_info.byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum, John Koblin and Jodi Kantor

title: Condé Nast Knows Faded Glory Is Not in Style
content: Anna Wintour is the embodiment of the glory days of the magazine dynasty. Now she is pitching its global, digital future.

title: A Top SoftBank Executive Wants $2 Billion in Pay. His Boss Disagrees.
content: The SoftBank founder, Masayoshi Son, is locked in a dispute over compensation that his key deputy, Marcelo Claure, insists he should be paid.

title: Public Displays of Resignation: Saying ‘I Quit’ Loud and Proud
content: People aren’t just leaving their jobs. They are broadcasting it.

title: A Journalist, a Philosophy Major and the Mad Scramble for Video Game Consoles
content: New gaming consoles remain in short supply this holiday season, spawning cottage industries of tipsters and scalpers making money off their scarcity.

more_info.byline: By Kellen Browning and Julie Creswell

title: Thefts, Always an Issue for Retailers, Become More Brazen
content: In recent months, robberies have been more visible, with several involving large groups rushing into stores and coming out with armloads of goods.

more_info.byline: By Michael Corkery and Sapna Maheshwari

title: Sharing Hard-Won Money Lessons to Build Generational Wealth
content: Wanting to help others in their communities, influencers of color who taught themselves how to pay off big debts and invest have developed audiences for their experience and advice.

org_facet: Federal Reserve Bank of St Louis

title: Why Do Christmas Trees Cost More This Year?
content: There are fewer tree farms these days, and some were hit by severe weather. Plus, both real and fake trees have been affected by higher shipping costs.

title: The Week in Business: Uncertainty Over the New Virus Variant
content: With much unknown about Omicron, President Biden announced travel restrictions and the stock market fell. Plus, the F.T.C. blocked a major chip deal.

org_facet: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries

title: In Its War on Covid-19, China Calls on ‘Little Inoculated Warriors’
content: The country regards children as crucial in its quest for herd immunity, but some parents, worried about the vaccines’ safety, are pushing back.

more_info.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Cao Li

title: How TikTok Reads Your Mind
content: It’s the most successful video app in the world. Our columnist has obtained an internal company document that offers a new level of detail about how the algorithm works.

title: How the Supply Chain Crisis Unfolded
content: The highly intricate and interconnected global supply chain is in upheaval, and in one way or another, much of the crisis can be traced to the outbreak of Covid-19.

more_info.byline: By Lazaro Gamio and Peter S. Goodman

title: Ken Moffett, Top Federal Mediator and Union Official, Dies at 90
content: In the busy summer of 1981, he mediated labor disputes involving baseball players, postal workers and air traffic controllers. He later briefly ran the players’ union.

title: Welcome to ‘Web3.’ What’s That?
content: Crypto enthusiasts see a future where the internet runs on blockchain-based tokens. In some spaces, these experiments are already well underway.

title: Is an All-Encompassing Mobility App Making a Comeback?
content: Versions of “mobility as a service,” or MaaS, apps exist, but companies and cities will need to come together for the idea to gain momentum.

title: Is Private Equity Overrated?
content: The strategy’s returns increasingly may not provide the stellar performance that investors have been sold.

title: How a Cream Cheese Shortage Is Affecting N.Y.C. Bagel Shops
content: Supply chain problems that have hit businesses across the country now threaten a quintessential New York treat.

title: Congo Ousts Mining Leader in a Cloud of Corruption Claims
content: The country’s president removed Albert Yuma Mulimbi as chairman of the state mining firm. Cobalt in Congo is a crucial resource in the global clean energy revolution.

more_info.byline: By Eric Lipton and Dionne Searcey

title: Overlooked No More: Julia Tuttle, the ‘Mother of Miami’
content: She worked tirelessly to revitalize the area now known as Miami, and is widely recognized as the only woman to have founded a major American city.

title: Susan Rosenblatt, Who Took On Big Tobacco, Dies at 70
content: She was the quieter half of a law partnership with her husband that pursued a suit against cigarette companies on behalf of Florida smokers.

title: Twitter’s heads of engineering and design will leave in a company shake-up.
content: Twitter’s head of engineering, Michael Montano, and its head of design and research, Dantley Davis, will leave the company by the end of the year.

title: The ‘Home Alone’ House Is on Airbnb. Sort Of.
content: Airbnb is renting out the house from “Home Alone” as part of a marketing campaign to make headlines. (Yes, it’s working.)

title: Omicron and Travel: So, Now Do I Need Trip Insurance?
content: In light of the new variant, is extra protection warranted for things like flight and lodging cancellations and quarantine hotels? It depends. Here’s what you need to know.

title: Ralph E. Ablon, Pioneer of Corporate Conglomerates, Dies at 105
content: After expanding a family scrap metal business into a hodgepodge of some 55 companies, he then successfully focused on the service economy.

title: Cognitive Rehab: One Patient’s Painstaking Path Through Long Covid Therapy
content: Samantha Lewis is relearning some basic aspects of her daily life after struggling with brain fog and other lingering symptoms for more than a year since being infected by the virus.

more_info.byline: By Pam Belluck and Alex Wroblewski

title: Stocks slide again after the jobs report sends mixed signals on the economy.
content: The S&P 500 is down nearly 4 percent since Omicron first began to make headlines.

title: A Tale of Redemptions
content: A popular route to the public market is looking shakier lately.

more_info.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni

title: The window to lift the debt limit is narrowing, an influential think tank warns.
content: The United States could default as soon as Dec. 21 if Democrats and Republicans fail to extend the Treasury Department’s borrowing authority.

more_info.byline: By Alan Rappeport and Emily Cochrane

title: The Markets Are Confused, but Wall Street Is Still Making Predictions
content: The emergence of the Omicron variant underlines the difficulty of planning even a few weeks ahead. Wall Street is forecasting next year’s precise market returns, regardless.

title: November Jobs Report Shows Weak Hiring but a Surge in the Labor Force
content: Employers reported adding 210,000 jobs, the year’s weakest showing, but there were also bright spots. The mixed picture complicated policy prospects.

more_info.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Talmon Joseph Smith

title: With Its Exit, Didi Sends a Signal: China No Longer Needs Wall Street
content: With plenty of its own money and a greater desire to control the private sector, Beijing is pushing its companies to tap investors closer to home.

more_info.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Paul Mozur

title: California regulators fine PG&E $125 million for 2019 fire.
content: Pacific Gas & Electric settled claims that one of its transmission lines caused the Kincade fire.

title: Most Covid Vaccines Will Work as Boosters, Study Suggests
content: In a comparison of seven different brands, researchers found that most shots give a strong boost, even in mix-and-match combinations.
